contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Mahavidyas.jpg|thumb|350px|Kali, Tara, Shodashi, Bhuvaneshvari, Bhairavi,<br /> Chhinnamasta, Dhumavati, Bagalamukhi, Matangi, and Kamala.]] '''Mahavidyas''' (''Great Wisdoms'') or ''Dasha-Mahavidyas'' are a group of ten aspects of the Divine Mother or [[Kali]] herself or [[Devi]] in [[Hinduism]]. The 10 Mahavidyas are Wisdom Goddesses, who represent a spectrum of feminine divinity, from horrific goddesses at one end, to the gentle at the other.<ref name=maha>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.co.in/books/about/Hindu_Goddesses.html?id=hgTOZEyrVtIC|title=Hindu Goddesses: Vision of the Divine Feminine in the Hindu Religious Tradition|last=Kinsley|first=David R|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publication|year=1987|pages=161–165|isbn=9788120803947}}</ref> The development of Mahavidyas represents an important turning point in the [[history of Shaktism]] as it marks the rise of [[Bhakti]] aspect in [[Shaktism]], which reached its zenith in 1700 CE. First sprung forth in the post-[[Puranic]] age, around 6th century C.E., it was a new theistic movement in which the supreme being was envisioned as female. A fact epitomized by texts like [[Devi-Bhagavata Purana]], especially its last nine chapters (31-40) of the seventh ''skandha'', which are known as the ''Devi Gita'', and soon became central texts of [[Shaktism]].<ref name=dev>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.co.in/books?id=OxayHczql9EC|title=The Devī Gītā: The Song of the Goddess|last=Brown|first=Charles Mackenzie|year=1998|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780791439401|page=23}}</ref> ==Etymology== [[Image:Kali by Raja Ravi Varma.jpg|thumb|upright|Kali – The first of the Ten Mahavidyas]] The name Mahavidyas comes from the [[Sanskrit]] roots, with ''[[maha]]'' meaning 'great' and ''[[vidya]]'' meaning, 'revelation, manifestation, knowledge, or wisdom.<ref name=dev/> ==Names== Shaktas believe, "the one Truth is sensed in ten different facets; the Divine Mother is adored and approached as ten cosmic personalities," the Dasa-Mahavidya ("ten-Mahavidyas").<ref>{{cite book|last=Shankarnarayanan|first=S|title=The Ten Great Cosmic Powers: Dasa Mahavidyas|publisher= Samata Books |location=Chennai|year=1972|edition=4|pages=4–5|isbn=9788185208381|url=http://books.google.co.in/books?id=I-sYAAAAIAAJ}}</ref> The Mahavidyas are considered [[Tantra|Tantric]] in nature, and are usually identified as:<ref>{{cite book|last=Kinsley|first=David R|title=Tantric Visions of the Divine Feminine: The Ten Mahavidyas|publisher= University of California Press |location=Berkeley|year= 1997|isbn=9780520204997|page=302|url=http://books.google.co.in/books?id=gkCsrfghkZ4C}}</ref> #''[[Kali]]'' – The ultimate form of Brahman, "Devourer of Time" (Supreme Deity of [[Shaktism#Kalikula: family of Kali|''Kalikula'']] systems) #''[[Tara (Devi)|Tara]]'' – The Goddess as Guide and Protector, or Who Saves.Who offers the ultimate knowledge which gives salvation (also known as Neel Saraswati). #''[[Tripura Sundari]]'' (''Shodashi'') – The Goddess Who is "Beautiful in the Three Worlds" (Supreme Deity of ''[[Shaktism#Srikula: family of Sri|Srikula]]'' systems); the "Tantric Parvati" or the "Moksha Mukta". #''[[Bhuvaneshvari]]'' – The Goddess as World Mother, or Whose Body is the Cosmos #''[[Bhairavi]]'' – The Fierce Goddess #''[[Chhinnamasta]]'' – The self-decapitated Goddess<ref name="Daniélou1991">{{cite book|first=Alain|last= Daniélou|title=The Myths and Gods of India: The Classic Work on Hindu Polytheism from the Princeton Bollingen Series|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1HMXN9h6WX0C&pg=PA284|year=1991|publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co|isbn=978-0-89281-354-4|pages=284–290}}</ref> #''[[Dhumavati]]'' – The Widow Goddess,or the Goddess of death. #''[[Bagalamukhi]]'' – The Goddess Who Paralyzes Enemies #''[[Matangi]]'' – the Prime Minister of Lalita (in ''Srikula'' systems); the "Tantric Saraswati" #''[[Kamalatmika|Kamala]]'' – The Lotus Goddess; the "Tantric Lakshmi" The Mahabhagavata Purana and Brhaddharma Purana however, list Shodashi (Sodasi) as Tripura Sundari, her another name.<ref name=maha/> The Guhyatiguyha-tantra associates the Mahavidyas with the ten [[Avatar]]s of [[Vishnu]], and states that the Mahavidyas are the source from which the avatars of Vishnu arose. All ten forms of the Goddess, whether gentle or terrifying, are worshiped as the universal Mother. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Mahavidya}} *[http://www.exoticindiaart.com/article/mahavidyas/ Wisdom Goddesses - Mahavidyas and the Assertion of Femininity in Indian Thought] {{Shaktism}} {{Hindu Culture and Epics}} [[Category:Hindu goddesses]] [[Category:Forms of Parvati]] [[Category:Mahavidyas| ]]
